casebody.data:
Nicholas Gomez v. The State. No. 4184. Decided October 18, 1916. Murder—Newly Discovered Evidence—Sufficiency of the Evidence. Where the motion for new trial, setting up newly discovered evidence, was not supported by affidavit, and the evidence was sufficient to sustain the conviction of murder, there was no reversible error. Appeal from the District Court of Fayette. Tried below before the Hon. Frank S. Boberts. Appeal from a conviction of murder; penalty, twenty-five years imprisonment in the penitentiary.

The opinion states the case.

No brief on file for appellant. C. C. McDonald, Assistant Attorney General, for the' State. *118DAVIDSON, Judge.

Appellant was convicted of murder, his punishment being assessed at twenty-five years confinement in the penitentiary.

No bills of exception were reserved, and no objection to the charge was presented. There is set up in the motion for a new trial the statement that there was newly discovered evidence. There is nothing to support this statement in the way of an affidavit. It is,- therefore, not discussed.

The only other matter pertains to the sufficiency of the evidence. That for the State is clear and positive that appellant shot .and killed deceased, another Mexican. Appellant’s contention was that deceased was shot by another party. To sustain this he introduced evidence. The jury believed the State’s witnesses, and we would not feel authorized to disturb the finding of the jury.

The 'judgment is affirmed.

Affirmed.
